content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::String)::Tuple{String, String}
    # Regular expressions to match questions and answers
    question_re = r"^(?:\s*##\s*)?Question:"m
    answer_re = r"^(?:\s*##\s*)?Answer:"m
    
    # Split the markdown text into lines
    lines = split(md, "\n")
    
    # Initialize variables to store the question and answer
    question = ""
    answer = ""
    
    # Loop through each line of the markdown text
    for (i, line) in enumerate(lines)
        if match(question_re, line) !== nothing
            # If we find a question header, start capturing text for the question
            question = strip(lines[i+1:]) # Start from the next line after the heading
        elseif match(answer_re, line) !== nothing
            # If we find an answer header, start capturing text for the answer
            answer = strip(lines[i+1:]) # Start from the next line after the heading
            break # Exit the loop once an answer is found
        end
    end
    
    return (question = question, answer = answer)
end
```

This function uses regular expressions to match `# Question` and `# Answer` headers. It then captures all text from the line following each header to the end of the document or until another header is encountered. The `strip()` function is used to remove leading whitespace and newlines from the captured text.
